This week, we're celebrating Maria Montessori's 150th birthday!

Dr. Montessori opened the doors to her first school in 1907. Through the learning materials she designed herself, students' natural curiosity and innate desire to learn took root and by 1911, the Montessori Method had grown into a worldwide movement.

Her legacy continues on today at Lumin Education, Dallas' first public Montessori school, where we encourage students to engage in hands-on projects and to follow their own instincts and curiosity to discover and embrace the world around them.

For more about Montessori at Montessori Institute of North Texas: https://www.facebook.com/montessoriMINT/photos/a.10150352271080924/10157431976030924/

Feeling estranged from your own child is painful.

Research indicates the most important predictor of a child‚Äôs emotional and psychological stability is the closeness of the parent/child relationship. If your child is not opening up when they are upset, the relationship may not be as close as it needs to be. There are two habits that parents routinely engage in that shut down communication and drive a child away: negating feelings and mistaking sympathy for empathy.

In many cases, honoring your child‚Äôs feelings is all they need to feel better. Simply knowing their parent understands allows them to feel secure and forge ahead. Some sympathetic statements, on the other hand, disrupt any chance of emotional attunement, instead of helping them work through their difficult feelings.

Dr. Erin Leonard discusses how to be a parent your child wants to confide in on the Gottman Relationship Blog: https://bit.ly/2DHZe8u

post_text: On April 25th, Dr. Andrew Willard will offer approaches to gain presence and momentum through challenging times. Did you know, according to research, today's mothers and fathers tend to focus more of their time and money on their children when compared to parents of the 1960s? This extra investment from parents is showing positive results, particularly when fathers are involved. For example, a 2017 study found that the amount of hands-on, sensitive engagement that dads were observed to have with babies at age 4 months and 24 months correlated positively with the baby's cognitive development at age 2. Lumin Education offers the Fatherhood Initiative program to provide fathers and families with tools and resources to prepare their children for school, normalize work-life balance, effectively communicate with their spouses. Click this link to read more about a father's impact on development: https://n.pr/2m6DZo4

Since 1978 Lumin Education has pioneered Montessori education for at risk children in Dallas. What started as a small class of 8 students, turned into a three-campus organization serving over 600 children and families each year.

Stephanie Barron is just one piece to this puzzle. As an alumna of Lumin Lindsley Park Community School, Stephanie went on to graduate high school at the top of her class and earn a scholarship to Babson College in Wellesley, Massachusetts. She founded a student-led volunteer organization, served as President of the Hispanic Organization for Latin Americans, in May 2018, graduated Cum Laude, with a degree in Business Administration, and is now working for an innovative marketing agency and serving as a volunteer with Lumin Education here in Dallas.

It is because of our community, and people like you who have made this a reality. Your commitment will continue to define the future for these children.

What story will your gift tell?
